tn.ref: General Information:
tn.text: Parallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: For the chief musician
tn.text: "This is for the director of music to use in worship,"

tn.ref: Jeduthun
tn.text: One of David's chief musicians had this same name. This may refer to him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: A psalm of David
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) David wrote the psalm or 2) the psalm is about David or 3) the psalm is in the style of David's psalms.

tn.ref: I will watch what I say
tn.text: Here "watch" is an idiom that mean "pay attention to." AT: "I will pay attention to the things that I say" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: so that I do not sin with my tongue
tn.text: Here "tongue" refers to the writer's speech. AT: "so that I do not speak an offense against Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: muzzle
tn.text: To "muzzle" means to keep a mouth shut. Here David means that he will not speak while he is with an evil person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: I kept silent; I kept back my words
tn.text: These two phrases mean the same thing and emphasize that the writer did not speak at all. AT: "I was completely silent" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

tn.ref: I kept back my words
tn.text: Here "my words" refers to the writer's speech. AT: "I did not speak" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: My heart became hot ... it burned like a fire
tn.text: Here "heart" represents the whole person. The anxious thoughts of the writer are spoken of as if they were a fire burning inside him. AT: "I became very anxious when I thought about these things" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: the end of my life ... the extent of my days
tn.text: These phrases mean basically the same thing. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: Show me how transient I am
tn.text: "Show me how brief my life is" or "Show me how soon I will die"

tn.ref: only the width of my hand
tn.text: The writer speaks of his lifespan is if it could be measured by the width of his hand. AT: "only a very short time" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: my lifetime is like nothing before you
tn.text: This simile states that the length of the writer's life is so short that it does not exist. This is an exaggeration to stress how short it is. AT: "the length of my life is barely any time at all" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])

tn.ref: Surely every man is a single breath
tn.text: The brevity of life is spoken of as if it was only as long as the time it takes for a person to breathe one breath. AT: "The time that humans live is as short as a single breath of a person." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Surely every man walks about like a shadow
tn.text: The lives of people are spoken of as if they are as insignificant as shadows. AT: "Everyone disappears like shadows do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: although they do not know who will receive them
tn.text: Here it is implied that they do not know what will happen to their wealth after they die. The full meaning of this statement can be made explicit. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: Now, Lord, for what am I waiting?
tn.text: The writer asks this question to emphasize that people cannot help him. This rhetorical question can be translated as a statement. AT: "So now, Yahweh, I can expect to receive nothing from anyone else." (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: I am silent ... cannot open my mouth
tn.text: These phrases mean basically the same thing. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: because it is you who has done it
tn.text: "because my punishment comes from you"

tn.ref: Stop wounding me
tn.text: God's punishment of the writer is spoken of as if God was wounding him with a weapon. AT: "please stop punishing me!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: I am overwhelmed
tn.text: "I am defeated completely"

tn.ref: the blow of your hand
tn.text: God's punishment of the writer is spoken of as if God was striking him with his fist. Here "hand" represents God's judgment. AT: "your judgment on me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: consume the things they desire like a moth
tn.text: God will take away the things they value in the same way as a moth eats a piece of cloth. AT: "consume the things they desire like a moth eats away at clothing" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: all people are nothing but vapor
tn.text: The writer speaks of the frailty of people as if they were mist that disappears quickly. AT: "everyone is completely fragile" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Hear my prayer ... listen to me ... listen to my weeping
tn.text: These three phrases mean basically the same thing and show how strongly the writer wants God to respond to him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: Do not be deaf to me
tn.text: The writer speaks of Yahweh's lack of response to him as if Yahweh was deaf. AT: "Do not ignore me as if you could not hear me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: I am like a foreigner with you, a refugee
tn.text: The writer speaks of Yahweh's lack of response as if Yahweh considered him to be a total stranger to him. AT: "I am like a complete stranger to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: Turn your gaze from me
tn.text: Here "your gaze" represents Yahweh's punishment. AT: "Please stop punishing me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: so that I may smile again
tn.text: Here "smile" is associated with being happy. AT: "so that I can be happy again" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
